title: Example charts
code:
lacZ_operon <- data.frame( start = c(361249, 361926, 363231, 366428), stop = c(361860, 363179, 366305, 367510), Gene_symbol = c("lacA", "lacY", "lacZ", "lacI"), Strand = c("minus", "minus", "minus", "minus"), NCBI_Gene_ID = as.character(c(945674, 949083, 945006, 945007)), Description = c("galactoside O-acetyltransferase", "lactose permease", "beta-galactosidase", "DNA-binding transcriptional repressor LacI") ) GC_chart(lacZ_operon, group = "Gene_symbol", height = "140px") %>% GC_labels() %>% GC_scaleBar(title = "0.2 kb", scaleBarUnit = 200, y=30) %>% GC_tooltip( formatter = " ID: {NCBI_Gene_ID}
Description: {Description}
Start: {start}
Stop: {stop}", ) %>% GC_title ("The Lac operon") %>% GC_footer( position = "middle", y = -30, subtitle = "Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655" ) %>% GC_coordinates( rotate = 0, tickValuesBottom = c(min(lacZ_operon$start), max(lacZ_operon$stop)), textStyle = list(x = -25, y = 22, fontSize = "10px"), tickStyle = list(lineLength = 10) ) %>% GC_legend(FALSE)

what: H. sapiens Hox genes using biomaRt to retrieve gene positions
title: Example charts
code: # Get HOX gene positions  library(biomaRt)  ensembl <- useMart("ensembl", dataset = "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")  hox_gene_sets <- list(   HOXA = c("HOXA1", "HOXA2", "HOXA3", "HOXA4", "HOXA5", "HOXA6", "HOXA7", "HOXA9", "HOXA10", "HOXA11", "HOXA13"),   HOXB = c("HOXB1", "HOXB2", "HOXB3", "HOXB4", "HOXB5", "HOXB6", "HOXB7", "HOXB8", "HOXB9", "HOXB13"),   HOXC = c("HOXC4", "HOXC5", "HOXC6", "HOXC8", "HOXC9", "HOXC10", "HOXC11", "HOXC12", "HOXC13"),   HOXD = c("HOXD1", "HOXD3", "HOXD4", "HOXD8", "HOXD9", "HOXD10", "HOXD11", "HOXD12", "HOXD13") )  get_gene_positions <- function(gene_list, cluster_name) {   result <- getBM(attributes = c('hgnc_symbol', 'chromosome_name', 'start_position', 'end_position'),                   filters = 'hgnc_symbol',                   values = gene_list,                   mart = ensembl)   transform(result, cluster = cluster_name) }  # Apply get_gene_positions to each gene set hox_gene_positions <- lapply(names(hox_gene_sets), function(cluster_name) {   get_gene_positions(hox_gene_sets[[cluster_name]], cluster_name) })  # Combine the results into a single data frame combined_hox_genes <- do.call(rbind, hox_gene_positions)  # Add gene names combined_hox_genes$name <- paste0(substr(combined_hox_genes$hgnc_symbol, 1, 3), substr(combined_hox_genes$hgnc_symbol, 5, nchar(combined_hox_genes$hgnc_symbol))) GC_chart(   combined_hox_genes,   start = "start_position",   stop = "end_position",   group = "cluster",   height = "400px",   cluster = "cluster") %>%   GC_sequence(y=45) %>%   GC_legend(FALSE) %>%   GC_clusterLabel(title = unique(combined_hox_genes$cluster)) %>%   GC_genes(arrowheadWidth = 0,            arrowheadHeight = 10,            arrowHeight = 10,   ) %>%    GC_scale(     cluster = c(3,4),     reverse = TRUE   ) %>%   GC_labels(label = "name",              adjustLabels = FALSE,             fontSize = 10,             itemStyle = list(               list(index = 5, x = 8)              )            ) %>%   GC_track(spacing=30)

title: GCVieweR
text: GCVieweR available GitHub
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("nvelden/GCVieweR")

title: GCVieweR
text: visualize single gene cluster, minimum requirements start stop positions gene, typically named “start” “stop”. addition group can defined used color coding genes used default categorical variable legend.
code: # Example data for a single Gene cluster ophA_cluster <- subset(ophA_clusters, cluster == "ophA")  GC_chart(ophA_cluster,           start = "start",           stop = "stop",           group = "class",           height = "150px"          )

title: GCVieweR
text: visualizing multiple gene clusters, additional variable needed used define clusters (shown ‘cluster’ column ). example overall chart height set “300px”. Since two distinct gene clusters height cluster 150px.
code: # Example data for two Gene clusters GC_chart(ophA_clusters,           start = "start",           stop = "stop",           group = "class",           cluster = "cluster",           height = "300px"          )

title: GCVieweR
text: GC_chartOutput() renderGC_chart() functions enable visualize gene clusters within Shiny applications.
code: # Load necessary libraries library(shiny) library(GCVieweR) # Define UI ui <- fluidPage(titlePanel("Omphalotin Gene Cluster Visualization"), mainPanel(# Output for GC_chart GC_chartOutput( "gcChart", width = "100%", height = "400px" ))) # Define server logic server <- function(input, output) { output$gcChart <- renderGC_chart({ GC_chart( ophA_clusters, cluster = "cluster", group = "class" ) %>% GC_title(title = c("O. olearius", "D. bispora")) %>% GC_labels("name") %>% GC_legend(position = "bottom") %>% GC_scaleBar() %>% GC_clusterLabel(title = "ophA") }) } # Run the application shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

title: GCVieweR
text: Customization functions default set alter styling gene clusters across chart. select specific cluster one can use cluster variable available customization functions. can select cluster either ’s name number. example title set first cluster y position height adjusted second cluster.
code: GC_chart(ophA_clusters, cluster = "cluster", group = "class", height = "220px") %>%   GC_title(title = "ophA Gene Clusters", cluster = 1) %>%   GC_labels(label = "name", cluster = "ophA", y = 10) %>%   GC_labels(label = "name", cluster = 2) %>%   GC_grid(cluster = 2, height = "150px")

title: GCVieweR
text: apply styling particular item within gene cluster, itemStyle variable can used. variable, accessible customization functions, requires list specifies index number desired item along intended styling attributes. ’s important note indexing itemStyle begins 0, following zero-based numbering system. example , 3rd label ophA cluster styled red color bold font. code also customizes labels cluster 2, 5th label similarly styled red bold, 4th label’s position adjusted.
code: GC_chart(ophA_clusters, cluster = "cluster", group = "class", height = "220px") %>%   GC_title(title = "ophA Gene Clusters", cluster = 1) %>%   GC_labels(label = "name",              cluster = "ophA",              y = 10,              itemStyle =                list(                 list(index = 2, fill = "red", fontWeight = "bold")                 )             ) %>%   GC_labels(     label = "name",      cluster = 2,     itemStyle =                list(                 list(index = 4, fill = "red", fontWeight = "bold"),                 list(index = 3, y = 20, x = -5)                 )     ) %>%   GC_grid(cluster = 2, height = "150px")

title: GCVieweR
text: GC_genes() function can used custom style genes. default genes color-coded based group column defined GC_chart() function, can altered using group variable GC_genes() function. Color coding uses “schemeCategory10” palette D3.js default. explore palettes, use colorScheme variable, define unique color set customColors. detailed color customization, see Colors section. Beyond color, GC_genes() function supports various CSS styles, stroke stroke width customization. default genes displayed arrows. alter appearance one can use arrowheadWidth, arrowheadHeight arrowHeight variables. addition positioning genes can altered using x y variables.
code: GC_chart(ophA_cluster, cluster = "cluster", group = "class", height = "150px") %>%   GC_genes(     group = "name",     show = TRUE,     customColors = c("blue", "red", "orange", "yellow", "purple", "green", "pink"), # A vector of color names     colorScheme = NULL, # One of D3.js build in colorSchemes                         # (eg. "schemeCategory10",                         # "schemeAccent", "schemeTableau10")     stroke = "grey",     strokeWidth = 2,     # Any other CSS style   ) %>%    GC_legend(FALSE) GC_chart(ophA_cluster, cluster = "cluster", group = "class", height = "150px") %>%   GC_genes(     x = 0,     y = 55,     strokeWidth = 1,      arrowheadWidth = 15, # 10     arrowheadHeight = 15, # 20     arrowHeight = 15 # 10    ) %>%    GC_legend(FALSE)

title: GCVieweR
text: gene cluster one can add title, gene labels, cluster label footer shown example . adjust positioning labels, x, y, position variables can used. Note example, GC_labels() employed twice: initially, sets labels uniformly gene clusters, specifically adjusts fourth eight label (considering index starts 0) cluster 2, ensure overlap. adjust position styling specific labels one can use cluster itemStyle variables. cluster variable one can select specific cluster name number. Using itemStyle variable one can provide list index number specific label styles applied . Note index itemStyle starts 0.
code: GC_chart(ophA_clusters, start = "start", stop = "stop", group = "class", cluster = "cluster", height = "420px" ) %>% GC_title( title = c("Gene Cluster"), subtitle = c("Omphalotus Olearius", "Dendrothele Bisporus") ) %>% GC_labels("name") %>% GC_clusterLabel(title = unique(ophA_clusters$cluster)) %>% GC_footer( title = c("Nr. of Genes: 7", "Nr. of Genes: 10"), subtitle = c("Locus: 2522 - 21,484", "Locus 19,236 - 43,005") ) GC_chart(ophA_clusters, group = "class", cluster = "cluster", height = "360px") %>% GC_title( c("Omphalotus Olearius", "Dendrothele Bisporus"), position = "left", x = 20) %>% GC_labels("name", y = 25) %>% GC_labels("name", cluster = 2, y = 25, itemStyle = list( list(index = 3, y = 50), list(index = 7, y = 50) ) ) %>% GC_footer( title = c("Nr. of Genes: 7", "Nr. of Genes: 10"), subtitle = c("Locus: 2522 - 21,484", "Locus 19,236 - 43,005"), position = "center", y = -10 ) GC_chart(ophA_clusters, group = "class", cluster = "cluster", height = "360px") %>% GC_labels("name", y = 30) %>% GC_labels("name", cluster = 2, y = 30, itemStyle = list( list(index = 3, y = 50, fill = "red"), list(index = 7, y = 50, fill = "red") ) )

title: GCVieweR
text: color legend genes can controlled GC_color function using colorScheme customColors variables.

title: GCVieweR
text: Defines predefined color scheme legend, “schemeCategory10” “schemeAccent” D3.js. Supported schemes include: schemeCategory10: array ten categorical colors. schemeAccent: array eight categorical colors. schemeDark2: array eight categorical colors. schemePaired: array twelve categorical colors. schemePastel1: array nine categorical colors. schemePastel2: array eight categorical colors. schemeSet1: array nine categorical colors. schemeSet2: array eight categorical colors. schemeSet3: array twelve categorical colors. schemeTableau10: array ten categorical colors, originally created Tableau.
code: GC_chart(ophA_cluster, group = "class", height = "100px") %>%   GC_color(colorScheme = "schemeAccent")

title: GCVieweR
text: Defines predefined set colors, customColors allows specifying exact colors group legend.
code: custom_colors <- c("#F8766D","#00BA38","#619CFF","#F564E3","#FFC61E","#00BFC4")  GC_chart(ophA_cluster, group = "class", height = "100px") %>%   GC_color(customColors = custom_colors)

title: GCVieweR
text: GC_scale()` function utilized adjusting chart’s scale. visibility scale can controlled hidden parameter, , set TRUE, hides axis. y parameter can used adjust horizontal position axis.
code: # With scale breaks GC_chart(ophA_cluster, group = "class", height = "100px") %>%   GC_scale(     hidden = FALSE,     y = 30) %>%    GC_legend(FALSE)

title: GCVieweR
text: GC_scale() function, parameters scale_breaks, scale_break_threshold, scale_break_padding can used avoid issues widely spaced genes within cluster. Setting scale_breaks TRUE introduces breaks genomic scale avoid long empty stretches. scale_break_threshold defines spacing percentage genes needed activate breaks. scale_break_padding controls padding around breaks. given example, scale break introduced cases intergenic region exceeds 20% total range gene cluster. Additionally, padding 1% added left right sides break.
code: # With scale breaks GC_chart(ophA_cluster, group = "class", height = "100px") %>%   GC_scale(     scale_breaks = TRUE,     scale_break_threshold = 20,     scale_break_padding = 1   ) %>%   GC_legend(FALSE)

title: GCVieweR
text: default minimum maximum genes start stop positions used position genes along sequence. use start stop parameters, values can adjusted. Scale breaks can added manually using thebreaks` parameter. provided example, adjustments made start stop range incorporate additional padding left right sides gene cluster. Additionally, scale break introduced remove extensive intergenic region exists gene 2 gene 3.
code: GC_chart(   ophA_cluster,    start = "start",    stop = "stop",    group = "class",    height = "100px") %>%   GC_scale(     start = 1522,      stop = 22484,     breaks =        list(         list(start = 5486, stop = 9336)       )     ) %>%   GC_legend(FALSE)

title: GCVieweR
text: scale can reversed setting reverse = TRUE
code: # With scale breaks GC_chart(ophA_cluster, group = "class", height = "100px") %>%   GC_scale(reverse = TRUE)

title: GCVieweR
text: scale can styled using tickStyle, textStyle lineStyle options. can pass valid CSS styles respective styling list(). amount ticks can specified using ticksCount option. ticksFormat parameter used define numerical labels tick marks formatted (see: link).
code: GC_chart(ophA_cluster, group = "class", height = "100px") %>%   GC_scale(     ticksFormat = ".1e", # Default: ",.0f"     ticksCount = 10,     tickStyle =        list(         stroke = "black",          strokeWidth = 2,          lineLength = 12         # Any other CSS styles         ),     textStyle =        list(         y = 15,         fill = "black",          fontSize = "12px",          fontFamily = "Arial"         # Any other CSS styles         ),     lineStyle = list(       stroke = "black",        strokeWidth = 2       # Any other CSS styles       )   ) %>%   GC_legend(FALSE)

title: GCVieweR
text: Gene coordinates can displayed GC_coordinates() function. overlapping coordinates occur, , default, shifted top axis clearer visualization. default overlapPercentage parameter set 2%. style ticks text can customized using tickStyle textStyle variables default, start stop positions gene indicated coordinates. However, can customize providing values top bottom ticks, using tickValuesTop tickValuesBottom options.
code: dbophA_cluster <- subset(ophA_clusters, cluster == "dbophA")  GC_chart(dbophA_cluster, group = "class",height = "100px") %>%   GC_coordinates(   rotate = -45,   yPositionTop = 55,   yPositionBottom = 45,   overlapPercentage = 2   ) %>%   GC_legend(FALSE) GC_chart(dbophA_cluster, group = "class",height = "100px") %>%   GC_coordinates(    tickStyle = list(stroke = "grey", strokeWidth = 1, lineLength = 10),    textStyle = list(fill = "gray", fontSize = "10px", fontFamily = "Arial", cursor = "default")    ) %>%    GC_legend(FALSE) GC_chart(dbophA_cluster, group = "class",height = "100px") %>%   GC_coordinates(     tickValuesTop = c(27371, 28937),     tickValuesBottom = c(25288, 27217)                      ) %>%    GC_legend(FALSE)

title: GCVieweR
text: sequence line GC_sequence() function initially presented solid black line, can customized sequenceStyle option. Additionally, markerStyle option allows adjusting style break markers.
code: GC_chart(   ophA_clusters, group = "class",   cluster = "cluster",   height = "150px") %>%   GC_sequence(     show = TRUE,     cluster = NULL,     y = 50,     sequenceStyle = list(       stroke = "grey",       strokeWidth = 1       # Any other CSS style     ),     markerStyle = list(       stroke = "grey",       strokeWidth = 1,       gap = 3,       tiltAmount = 5       # Any other CSS style     )   ) %>%   GC_legend(FALSE)

title: GCVieweR
text: scalebar can added gene cluster chart using GC_scaleBar(). function, default, displays scale bar 1000 base pairs (bp) labeled “1kb”. scalebar’s position label can customized using x, y, labelPosition parameters. CSS styles can added modify labels. appearance scalebar line ticks adjustable scaleBarLine scaleBarTick options.
code: GC_chart(ophA_clusters, group = "class", cluster = "cluster", height = "150px") %>%   GC_scaleBar(     title = "1kb",     scaleBarUnit = 1000     ) %>%   GC_legend(FALSE) GC_chart(ophA_clusters, group = "class", cluster = "cluster", height = "150px") %>%   GC_scaleBar(     title = "1kb",     scaleBarUnit = 1000,     cluster = NULL,     x = 0,     y = 10,     labelStyle = list(       labelPosition = "left",       fontSize = "10px",       fontFamily = "sans-serif",       fill = "black",           cursor = "default"        # Any other CSS style for the label     ),     textPadding = 2,     scaleBarLineStyle = list(       stroke = "black",       strokeWidth = 1       # Any other CSS style for the line     ),     scaleBarTickStyle = list(       stroke = "black",       strokeWidth = 1          # Any other CSS style for the tick     )   )

title: GCVieweR
text: default, tooltip gene chart displays start stop positions gene hovering . positions dynamically replaced actual start stop data values gene. can customize text tooltip using formatter variable. example , tooltip customized include gene’s start stop positions also name. gene name pulled ‘name’ column data set.
code:
GC_chart(ophA_cluster, group = "class", height = "150px") %>% GC_tooltip( formatter = "Gene: {name}
Start: {start}
Stop: {stop}", ) %>% GC_legend(FALSE)

title: GCVieweR
text: prevent gene overlaps, genes automatically separated distinct tracks. GC_track function track-based separation can switched spacing tracks can adjusted. example track switched first cluster spacing second cluster increased 40 50. Note: GC_track() function must called setting genes, labels coordinates proper effect.
code: GC_chart(   subset(human_hox_genes, cluster %in% c("HOXA", "HOXB")),   group = "name",   cluster = "cluster",   height = "300px"    ) %>%    GC_labels(label = "name") %>%   GC_labels(label = "name",              cluster = 1,              itemStyle = list(list(index = 2, x=-10))             ) %>%   GC_legend(FALSE) %>%   GC_track(track = FALSE, cluster = 1) %>%   GC_track(cluster = 2, spacing = 50)

title: GCVieweR
text: GC_grid() function can used modify grid specific cluster. example height margins adjusted second gene cluster.
code: # With scale breaks GC_chart(ophA_clusters, group = "class", cluster = "cluster",          height = "200px" # Total height                            # since there are 2 clusters in the data                            # the height of each cluster will be 100px          ) %>%    GC_grid(     cluster = 2, # Set to NULL to adjust all clusters     height = "80px",     margin = list(left = "5px", right = "5px", top = "0px", bottom = "0px")   ) %>%    GC_legend(FALSE)

text: can install development version GCVieweR GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("nvelden/GCVieweR")

title: Gene Cluster Visualizations in R
text: example demonstrates using GCVieweR plot gene cluster genomic sequence, using start stop positions gene. genes grouped class. Additional functions used include title, labels, legend, scale bar.
code: library(GCVieweR)  # Data gene_cluster <- data.frame(   name = c("ophB1", "ophC", "ophA", "ophD", "ophB2", "ophP", "ophE"),   start = c(2522, 5286, 9536, 12616, 13183, 19346, 20170),   stop = c(4276, 4718, 10904, 11859, 15046, 16016, 21484),   class = c("Monooxygenase", "NTF2-like", "Methyltransferase",    "O-acyltransferase", "Monooxygenase", "Prolyloligopeptidase",    "F-box/RNHI-like") )  # Chart GC_chart(gene_cluster, group = "class", height = "200px") %>%   GC_title("omphalotin gene cluster") %>%   GC_labels("name") %>%   GC_legend(position = "bottom") %>%   GC_scaleBar() %>%    GC_clusterLabel(title = "ophA")

code: if (interactive()) { library(shiny) library(GCVieweR) ui <- fluidPage( titlePanel("Omphalotin Gene Cluster Visualization"), mainPanel( GC_chartOutput("gcChart", width = "100%", height = "500px") ) ) server <- function(input, output) { output$gcChart <- renderGC_chart({ GC_chart( ophA_clusters, # Ensure 'ophA_clusters' data is defined or available cluster = "cluster", group = "class" ) %>% GC_title(title = c("O. olearius", "D. bispora")) %>% GC_labels("name") %>% GC_legend(position = "bottom") %>% GC_scaleBar() %>% GC_clusterLabel(title = "ophA") }) } shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server) }

what: Create a GC Chart Visualization — GC_chart
title: Create a GC Chart Visualization — GC_chart
text: Generates interactive GC chart genomic data.

title: Create a GC Chart Visualization — GC_chart
code: GC_chart(   data,   start = "start",   stop = "stop",   cluster = NULL,   group = NULL,   width = "100%",   height = "400px",   background_color = "#0000",   elementId = NULL )

title: Create a GC Chart Visualization — GC_chart
text: data Data frame containing genomic information. start Column name indicates start positions. Default "start". stop Column name indicates stop positions. Default "stop". cluster Optional column name used clustering purposes. Default NULL. group Column name used gene grouping influence color aesthetics. width Width specification chart, '100%' 500. Default unspecified. height Height specification chart, '400px' 300. Default unspecified. background_color Background color chart, specified color code. Default transparent. elementId Optional identifier string widget. Default NULL.

title: Create a GC Chart Visualization — GC_chart
text: GC chart widget.

title: Create a GC Chart Visualization — GC_chart

what: Set or Update Cluster Labels for a GC Chart — GC_clusterLabel
title: Set or Update Cluster Labels for a GC Chart — GC_clusterLabel
text: function allows set update labels specified clusters within GC chart. provides flexibility terms title, visibility, width, position, additional customization options.

title: Set or Update Cluster Labels for a GC Chart — GC_clusterLabel
code: GC_clusterLabel(   GC_chart,   title = NULL,   show = TRUE,   width = "100px",   cluster = NULL,   position = "left",   wrapLabel = TRUE,   wrapOptions = list(),   ... )

title: Set or Update Cluster Labels for a GC Chart — GC_clusterLabel
text: GC_chart GC chart object. title Character vector. title cluster label. Default NULL. show Logical. Whether show cluster label. Default TRUE. width Character. width cluster label. Default "100px". cluster Numeric character vector. Clusters GC chart update. Default NULL. position Character. Position label, either "left" "right". Default "left". wrapLabel Logical. Indicates whether label wrapped. Default TRUE. wrapOptions List. Specifies wrapping options. Default empty List. ... Additional customization arguments cluster label, 'fontSize', 'fontStyle', 'fontWeight', 'fontFamily', 'cursor', etc.

title: Set or Update Cluster Labels for a GC Chart — GC_clusterLabel
text: Updated GC chart new modified cluster labels.

title: Update Scale of a GC Chart Cluster — GC_scale
text: GC_chart GC chart object. cluster Numeric character vector specifying clusters GC chart update. start Numeric vector indicating starting point scale. Default NULL. stop Numeric vector indicating stopping points scale. Default NULL. hidden Logical flag indicating whether axis hidden. Default FALSE. breaks List specifying settings scale breaks. Default empty list (). reverse Logical flag indicating whether reverse scale corresponding cluster. Default FALSE. scale_breaks Logical flag indicating scale breaks employed. Default FALSE. scale_break_threshold Numeric value indicating threshold percentage determining scale breaks. Default 20. scale_break_padding Numeric value indicating padding either side scale break. Default 1. ticksCount Numeric value indicating number ticks scale. Default 20. ticksFormat Character string indicating format ticks. Default ",.0f". y Numeric value indicating y-position x-axis. Default 30. tickStyle List specifying style ticks. textStyle List specifying style tick text. lineStyle List specifying style axis line. ... Additional arguments scale settings.

title: Update Scale of a GC Chart Cluster — GC_scale
text: Updated GC chart new scale settings.
